awd_titl_txt: The Sunflower Conjecture, Disjunctive Normal Forms, and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a rich history of symbiosis between computer science and mathematics. This award is aimed at further strengthening this connection, and in particular between the fields of theoretical computer science and combinatorics. This project centers around a fundamental open problem in combinatorics, called the sunflower conjecture. This problem originated in 1960 and is still unanswered, despite having numerous applications in mathematics and in computer science. Recent work by the PI has made significant progress towards resolving the conjecture, and this project is focused on continuing this work. The project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.

Concretely, the project explores a correspondence between set systems (also known as hypergraphs) and DNFs (Disjunctive Normal Forms). Building upon recent work by the PI, the project demonstrates how tools used to study DNFs can be instrumental in studying set systems, and proposes a unified and versatile framework to make progress on several well-studied conjectures in mathematics and theoretical computer science about the structure of set systems and DNFs. These also include, beyond the sunflower conjecture and related problems in combinatorics, problems related to DNF compression and the Fourier structure of DNFs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The sunflower conjecture is an important open problem in combinatorics, originating from the work of Erdos and Rado from the 1960s. It speculates that in any large enough family of sets, there must exist sets that form a special structure called a "sunflower". The existence of such sunflower structure has proven to be pivotal to many applications in combinatorics and theoretical computer science, and hence it is crucial that we understand what is threshold of the size of the family that guarantees the existence of sunflowers. A few years ago, I and colleagues were able to vastly improve the known bound for this threshold, getting much closer to the conjectured bound. The goal of this award is to explore new applications for the techniques that we developed.

I worked on this research with several graduate students. Jointly we found several new applications for these techniques. One of these applications is in communication complexity. This is a vibrant area of research in theoretical computer science, which studies the amount of communication needed to solve various distributed computational problems. We used these techniques to better understand the amount of communication needed for some structured communication problems called "lifted functions", which are important in many applications.

In another direction, we used similar techniques in game theory. We developed a new fast algorithm that can find an optimal strategy in certain games whose description size is exponential. Previous algorithms required exponential time to run because of the description size, and we found a clever way to get around this using techniques based on sunflowers.

In yet another direction, we explored potential connections to the emerging area of high dimensional expanders. This is an active area of study that sits in between mathematics and computer science. In recent years it proved to be pivotal in the resolution of several major open problems, such as the design of optimal sampling algorithms for central problems, and the design of good quantum error correcting codes. In my work in this area, we developed the theory of high dimensional expanders based on techniques related to sunflowers.
